text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on March 11 in history.
1544 - Italian poet Torquato Tasso, born. Best remembered for his epic poem "Gerusalemme Liberata", an idealised story about the First Crusade.
1702 - The first English daily newspaper to meet with some success, The Daily Courant, was launched near Fleet Street in London.
1845 - In New Zealand, further Maori uprisings occurred against British rule.
1851 - The first performance of Giuseppe Verdi's opera "Rigoletto" was given in Venice.
1885 - Sir Malcolm Campbell, British businessman and world speed record holder on land and water, born.
1892 - Raoul Walsh, U.S. film director, born. In films from 1914, he was best known for his American gangster films "High Sierra", "White Heat" and "The Roaring Twenties".
1916 - Harold Wilson, British statesman and politician, born. He prime minister from 1964-1970 and from 1974-1976.
1917 - In World War One, General Maude with 50,000 British and Indian troops marched into Baghdad capturing 9,000 Turkish prisoners.
1926 - Irish statesman Eamon de Valera resigned as head of Sinn Fein. He later formed the Fianna Fail party.
1931 - Rupert Murdoch, Australian newspaper and television magnate, born.
1935 - Hermann Goering officially created the German Air Force, the Luftwaffe.
1938 - Artur Seyss-Inquart became Chancellor of Austria, replacing Kurt von Schuschnigg.
1941 - The U.S. Congress passed the Lend-Lease Bill, which enabled Britain to borrow money to buy additional food and arms during World War Two.
1955 - Sir Alexander Fleming, Scottish bacteriologist who discovered penicillin (1928), died. He won the Nobel prize in 1945.
1960 - At Cape Canaveral, Pioneer V was launched into orbit around the sun.
1973 - Gaullists and their allies retained an absolute majority in the second ballot of the French General Election.
1981 - Chilean President Pinochet was sworn in for eight-year term as president.
1985 - Mikhail Gorbachev became head of the Soviet Union following the death of Konstantin Chernenko. At 54, he was the youngest member of the ruling Politburo.
1985 - The Egyptian Al-Fayed brothers won control of the House of Fraser in London and thus gained control of the department store Harrods.

1990 - The Lithuanian Parliament proclaimed the restoration of the Baltic Republic's pre- World War Two independence from the Soviet Union. Lithuania was the first Soviet Republic to break away from Communist control.
1994 - Christian Democrat Eduardo Frei, following in his father's footsteps, was sworn in as Chile's president and pledged to help the poor.
1994 - Paratroopers in Bophuthatswana shot dead three white neo-Nazis who had entered the black homeland to block a popular uprising in support of South Africa's first all-race election.
1994 - Slovak Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar and his government were ousted by parliament in a vote of no-confidence.
1995 - Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, arrived in New York.
1995 - A lone gunman shot dead Burundi's Energy and Mines Minister Ernest Kabushemeye in the capital Bujumbura.
